title: Kruis Score for Diagnosis of Irritable Bowel Syndrome (IBS)
description: Determines presence of IBS using clinically significant weighted criteria including symptoms and laboratory parameters to differentiate IBS from organic gastrointestinal disease

parameters.name: symptoms_present
parameters.description: Symptoms of abdominal pain, flatulence, or bowel irregularity present

parameters.name: pain_description
parameters.description: Pain described as burning, cutting, very strong, or similar severe descriptors

parameters.name: abnormal_physical_findings
parameters.description: Abnormal physical findings on examination (red flag)

parameters.name: esr_over_10
parameters.description: Erythrocyte sedimentation rate (ESR) greater than 10 mm/hr (red flag)

parameters.name: wbc_over_10000
parameters.description: White blood cell count greater than 10,000/μL (red flag)

parameters.name: low_hemoglobin
parameters.description: Low hemoglobin (female < 12 g/dL; male < 14 g/dL) indicating anemia (red flag)

parameters.name: history_blood_in_stool
parameters.description: History of blood in stool (red flag)

result.name: kruis_ibs_score
result.description: Kruis Score calculation for IBS diagnosis with symptom assessment and red flag evaluation

ranges.interpretation: IBS diagnosis unlikely. Consider further evaluation for organic gastrointestinal disease, especially if red flags are present.
IBS diagnosis likely. Symptoms consistent with irritable bowel syndrome based on validated criteria.

references: Kruis W, Thieme C, Weinzierl M, Schüssler P, Holl J, Paulus W. A diagnostic score for the irritable bowel syndrome. Its value in the exclusion of organic disease. Gastroenterology. 1984 Jul;87(1):1-7.
Frigerio G, Beretta A, Orsenigo G, Tadeo G, Imperiali G, Minoli G. Irritable bowel syndrome. Still a diagnosis of exclusion? Dig Dis Sci. 1992 Jan;37(1):164-7.
Bellini M, Tosetti C, Costa F, Biagi S, Stasi C, Del Punta A, et al. The general practitioner's approach to irritable bowel syndrome: from intention to practice. Dig Liver Dis. 2005 Dec;37(12):934-9.
Thompson WG. The road to Rome. Gastroenterology. 2006 Nov;131(5):1622-6.
formula: Score = (+34 if symptoms present) + (+16 if duration >2 years) + (+23 if severe pain) + (+14 if alternating bowel habits) + (-47 if abnormal physical findings) + (-13 if ESR >10) + (-50 if WBC >10,000) + (-98 if low hemoglobin) + (-98 if blood in stool history)
notes: Developed in 1984 by Kruis et al. as one of the first scoring systems for IBS diagnosis
Incorporates both positive symptoms and negative red flag indicators
Score ≥44 points suggests IBS diagnosis with 81% sensitivity and 91% specificity
Red flags (negative points) help exclude organic gastrointestinal disease
Has largely been superseded by Rome criteria in clinical practice but remains useful for research
Laboratory tests (ESR, WBC, hemoglobin) are integral to the scoring system
Originally designed to differentiate IBS from organic bowel disease
Emphasizes the importance of symptom duration (>2 years) in IBS diagnosis
Any presence of red flags warrants further evaluation for organic pathology
